title: 109_hr1418
content: The Act may be cited as the "Infertility Coverage for Federal Employees, Military Personnel, and their Families Act". It provides infertility benefits. The "Infertility Coverage for Federal Employees, Military Personnel, and their Families Act" amends Section 8904 of title 5, United States Code to require health benefits plans to cover the diagnosis and treatment of infertility, including assisted reproductive technology procedures, without greater copayments or deductibles than obstetrical benefits. The "Infertility Coverage for Federal Employees, Military Personnel, and their Families Act" mandates coverage for infertility treatments under specific conditions at accredited medical facilities. The "Infertility Coverage for Federal Employees, Military Personnel, and their Families Act" requires coverage for infertility treatments at accredited facilities, with limits on the number of attempts for live births and oocyte retrievals. The "Infertility Coverage for Federal Employees, Military Personnel, and their Families Act" mandates coverage for infertility treatments with limits on attempts for live births and oocyte retrievals, with exceptions for religious objections. The "Infertility Coverage for Federal Employees, Military Personnel, and their Families Act" mandates coverage for infertility treatments, defining infertility as the inability to conceive after 12 months of regular sexual relations or a demonstrated condition causing infertility. Nonexperimental assisted reproductive technology procedures are also included. The "Infertility Coverage for Federal Employees, Military Personnel, and their Families Act" requires health care plans to cover infertility treatments, including nonexperimental assisted reproductive technology procedures recognized by reputable medical organizations or Federal agencies. Regulations will be prescribed by the Office to implement this mandate. The "Infertility Coverage for Federal Employees, Military Personnel, and their Families Act" mandates health care plans to cover infertility treatments, including assisted reproductive technology procedures. Coverage for infertility diagnosis or treatment must not have higher copayments or deductibles than obstetrical benefits. Procedures are required only if less costly treatments have been unsuccessful, and must be performed at facilities meeting medical standards. The "Infertility Coverage for Federal Employees, Military Personnel, and their Families Act" requires health care plans to cover infertility treatments meeting medical standards set by recognized organizations or Federal agencies. Laboratories involved must be accredited by specific programs or agencies. The "Infertility Coverage for Federal Employees, Military Personnel, and their Families Act" mandates that coverage for certain procedures is limited to a maximum number of attempts to achieve a live birth or oocyte retrieval. If a live birth occurs after the third attempt, the limit is increased to five attempts, and after the fourth attempt, the limit is increased to six. The Act mandates coverage limits for procedures to achieve a live birth or oocyte retrieval, with increases allowed after the third and fourth attempts. Coverage is not permitted if objected to on religious grounds or if not performed by a physician. The Act defines infertility as the inability to conceive after 12 months of regular sexual relations or a demonstrated condition causing infertility. Nonexperimental assisted reproductive technology procedures include IVF, gamete intrafallopian transfer, and other recognized treatments.
